customer_addr:
15412 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32413

citations.narrative:
The facility failed to keep some bird enclosures in good repair:
- The African penguin enclosure housing two penguins has cracked concrete in areas where the birds have access. The
cracks go through the impervious coating and expose the concrete below.
- The exhibit stands inside the aviary building contain multiple food and water bowl holders and enrichment chains that
are heavily rusted.
Cracked concrete and rusty surfaces can be signs degradation which can worsen over time, increasing the risk of
breakage, enclosure compromise, and possible injury to the birds.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair.
Correct by 6/15/2025.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility continues to not maintain a program of adequate veterinary care by failing to provide the availability of
appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and services:
- According to conversations with facility veterinary staff, financial constraints continue to result in delinquencies and non-
payments for laboratory services deemed necessary by veterinary staff, resulting in the denial of services.
- According to conversations with facility veterinary staff, in house bloodwork equipment is not going to be serviced
anymore nor will supplies be delivered to run its functions, due to a change in contract with prior participating entities.
- From conversations with facility water quality staff, they are unable to clear the 4 inch diameter pipe that feeds the
facility's water from the Bay, reducing flow rate. According to them, it is due to a variety of reasons: a lack of available
equipment to clean the small diameter pipe, sea turtle nesting season, and resistant contractors to work with the facility.
- In conversation with the newly contracted attending veterinarian, their recommendation is that the facility needs an
onsite/near onsite veterinarian and another veterinary technician.
Properly functioning equipment, appropriate facilities, adequate numbers of trained employees, quick access to supplies,
medications, and testing services is necessary for diagnosing, treating and maintaining the health of the animals.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that includes the availability of
appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and services.

The facility continues to fail to maintain the marine mammal enclosures in good repair. During a follow up routine
inspection of the facility, USDA inspectors continue to identify several areas in need of repair:
- The far west dolphin pool has previously identified cracks in the walls and surrounding concrete which has still not been
addressed and is continuing to break down. These areas have flaking paint, exposed aggregate, and loose stone or
cement pieces which could fall into the water.
- According to conversations with a facility representative, the 4 inch diameter pipe that pulls water from the Bay into the
facility for its water supply is blocked, allowing no more than 40% intake on an ideal day.
Enclosures that fall into states of disrepair may no longer be able to safely contain the animals and can lead to health and
well-being hazards to the animals within.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be maintained in good repair.

The facility continues to fail to provide protection from the weather or direct sunlight. Although previously identified, the
facility has not provided shade over the far side of dolphin east pool where dry guest interactions are done, or the over the
main show stage where the dolphins station for food during training sessions with the trainers or during public guest
interactions after shows. At the time of inspection, guest and dolphin interactions were observed at the main stadium pool.
Two groups were observed, one on the east and one on the west side of the pool. No additional shade or shelter was
provided to either group and the dolphins were positioned looking directly toward the sun, especially on the east side of
the enclosure.
Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable and adversely affect the animal’s health, especially skin and eye health.
Natural or artificial shelter shall be provided for all marine mammals kept outdoors to afford them protection from the
weather or from direct sunlight.

The facility continues to fail to maintain an effective perimeter fence:
- Facility maintenance equipment and debris were found along the perimeter fence's edge.
Animals and unauthorized people can use structures laying along the perimeter fence to enter and exit the area and gain
access to the animals behind it.
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects marine mammals by restricting animals and unauthorized
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the' marine mammals, and so that it can function as a
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility when appropriate.

The facility continues to not have enough employees to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry practices set forth in
this subpart.
The facility continues to be unable to make the corrections necessary to comply with the Animal Welfare Act, as indicated
by the repeat designations on this inspection report's noncompliant items identified. The facility's current employees have
to fulfill collateral duties in order to run business operations at their current pace.
A sufficient number of adequately trained staff to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry can ensure that optimal
welfare and care can be provided for the animals maintained at this facility.
A sufficient number of adequately trained employees or attendants, responsible to management and working in concert
with the attending veterinarian, must be utilized to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry practices set forth in this
subpart.

The facility failed to provide marine mammal medical records for APHIS inspection. Since the changeover of attending
veterinarians from the last inspection, the new attending veterinarian and veterinary staff were unable to generate medical
summaries for each animal. They indicated they had notes on their personal devices, but had not yet found the time to put
their findings into official medical records.
Accurate and well kept marine mammal medical records ensure that adequate veterinary care is being administered.
Individual animal medical records must be kept and made available for APHIS inspection.
Correct by 6/14/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility failed to keep some bird enclosures in good repair: 
 
- The African penguin enclosure housing two penguins has cracked concrete in areas where the birds have access. The 
cracks go through the impervious coating and expose the concrete below. 
 
- The exhibit stands inside the aviary building contain multiple food and water bowl holders and enrichment chains that 
are heavily rusted. 
 
Cracked concrete and rusty surfaces can be signs degradation which can worsen over time, increasing the risk of 
breakage, enclosure compromise, and possible injury to the birds. 
 
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair. 
 
Correct by 6/15/2025. 
2.40(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility continues to not maintain a program of adequate veterinary care by failing to provide the availability of 
appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and services: 
 
- According to conversations with facility veterinary staff, financial constraints continue to result in delinquencies and non-
payments for laboratory services deemed necessary by veterinary staff, resulting in the denial of services. 
 
- According to conversations with facility veterinary staff, in house bloodwork equipment is not going to be serviced 
anymore nor will supplies be delivered to run its functions, due to a change in contract with prior participating entities.

- From conversations with facility water quality staff, they are unable to clear the 4 inch diameter pipe that feeds the 
facility's water from the Bay, reducing flow rate. According to them, it is due to a variety of reasons: a lack of available 
equipment to clean the small diameter pipe, sea turtle nesting season, and resistant contractors to work with the facility. 
 
- In conversation with the newly contracted attending veterinarian, their recommendation is that the facility needs an 
onsite/near onsite veterinarian and another veterinary technician. 
 
Properly functioning equipment, appropriate facilities, adequate numbers of trained employees, quick access to supplies, 
medications, and testing services is necessary for diagnosing, treating and maintaining the health of the animals.  
 
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that includes the availability of 
appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and services. 
3.101(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility continues to fail to maintain the marine mammal enclosures in good repair. During a follow up routine 
inspection of the facility, USDA inspectors continue to identify several areas in need of repair: 
 
- The far west dolphin pool has previously identified cracks in the walls and surrounding concrete which has still not been 
addressed and is continuing to break down. These areas have flaking paint, exposed aggregate, and loose stone or 
cement pieces which could fall into the water.  
 
- According to conversations with a facility representative, the 4 inch diameter pipe that pulls water from the Bay into the 
facility for its water supply is blocked, allowing no more than 40% intake on an ideal day. 
 
Enclosures that fall into states of disrepair may no longer be able to safely contain the animals and can lead to health and 
well-being hazards to the animals within.  
 
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be maintained in good repair. 
3.103(b)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility continues to fail to provide protection from the weather or direct sunlight. Although previously identified, the 
facility has not provided shade over the far side of dolphin east pool where dry guest interactions are done, or the over the 
main show stage where the dolphins station for food during training sessions with the trainers or during public guest 
interactions after shows. At the time of inspection, guest and dolphin interactions were observed at the main stadium pool. 
Two groups were observed, one on the east and one on the west side of the pool. No additional shade or shelter was 
provided to either group and the dolphins were positioned looking directly toward the sun, especially on the east side of 
the enclosure.  
 
Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable and adversely affect the animal’s health, especially skin and eye health.

Natural or artificial shelter shall be provided for all marine mammals kept outdoors to afford them protection from the 
weather or from direct sunlight. 
3.103(c)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility continues to fail to maintain an effective perimeter fence: 
 
- Facility maintenance equipment and debris were found along the perimeter fence's edge. 
 
Animals and unauthorized people can use structures laying along the perimeter fence to enter and exit the area and gain 
access to the animals behind it.  
 
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects marine mammals by restricting animals and unauthorized 
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the' marine mammals, and so that it can function as a 
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility when appropriate. 
3.108(a)  Repeat
   
Employees or attendants. 
The facility continues to not have enough employees to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry practices set forth in 
this subpart. 
 
The facility continues to be unable to make the corrections necessary to comply with the Animal Welfare Act, as indicated 
by the repeat designations on this inspection report's noncompliant items identified. The facility's current employees have 
to fulfill collateral duties in order to run business operations at their current pace. 
 
A sufficient number of adequately trained staff to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry can ensure that optimal 
welfare and care can be provided for the animals maintained at this facility.  
 
A sufficient number of adequately trained employees or attendants, responsible to management and working in concert 
with the attending veterinarian, must be utilized to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry practices set forth in this 
subpart. 
3.110(d) 
   
Veterinary care. 
The facility failed to provide marine mammal medical records for APHIS inspection. Since the changeover of attending 
veterinarians from the last inspection, the new attending veterinarian and veterinary staff were unable to generate medical 
summaries for each animal. They indicated they had notes on their personal devices, but had not yet found the time to put 
their findings into official medical records.

Accurate and well kept marine mammal medical records ensure that adequate veterinary care is being administered. 
 
Individual animal medical records must be kept and made available for APHIS inspection. 
 
Correct by 6/14/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
